summary: the extra stretch of coastline on shiretoko peninsula near the town of rausu has risen from the sea surface . melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop , pivoting the underwater area into the air . the mass , which has risen some 30 to 50ft above sea level , measures roughly 1,000 - 1,640 ft long , and 100ft wide .

aspect: 1. Unexpected emergence of coastline in Hokkaido, Japan due to landslide.
2. Aerial survey indicates landslide as cause of coastline emergence.
3. New coastline measures 1,000- 1,640ft long and 100ft wide.
4. Residents heard no sounds or felt tremors during emergence.
7. Marine organisms still attached to land mass.
2. What - Coastline emergence due to landslide
4. Where - Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Hokkaido Island, Japan
6. Why - Not expected to expand further.
explain: "The given aspect highlights an unanticipated event that happened in Hokkaido, Japan, where a part of the coastline emerged from the sea surface due to a landslide. This event is surprising and unexpected, and it took place in an area near the town of Rausu on the Shiretoko Peninsula. The rise in land mass occurred because of the melting of ice and snow, which caused a section of the land to drop, and in turn raised the underwater area into the air. The emerged area is approximately 100 feet wide and 1000-1640 feet long. This aspect talks about a natural disaster that caused a significant change to the landscape, and it underscores the impact of climate change on our planet."

The aspect suggests that the recent emergence of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu Town is not due to rising sea levels or any other geological activity, but rather a landslide caused the underwater area to rise up to 1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide.
The new coastline at the Shiretoko Peninsula near the town of Rausu is measured to be 1,000 - 1,640 ft long and 100 ft wide.
This means that the residents living in the area did not experience any sounds or feel any vibrations during the emergence of the landmass.

This aspect states that there will be no further expansion or growth in the aspect of the given topic. It suggests that the previously mentioned increase in landmass due to melting ice and snow will not continue to grow or expand in size; rather, it will remain the same.
The aspect states that the given information about the Shiretoko Peninsula in Japan rising from the sea surface is not related to the Nepal earthquake.

According to the given aspect, marine organisms or sea creatures are still attached to the land mass that has risen from the sea surface in Shiretoko peninsula. These organisms have not been affected by the rising landmass and are still living in their natural habitat.

A core idea of the given aspect is that the extra stretch of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula has risen from the sea surface due to melting ice and snow causing a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air.
Residents of Hokkaido, Japan are affected by the landmass rising from the sea surface on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu Town.

The aspect of coastline emergence due to landslide refers to the phenomenon where a section of the coastline near the town of Rausu on Shiretoko Peninsula has risen from the sea surface due to melting ice and snow. This has caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air, creating a mass that measures roughly 1,000-1,640 ft long and 100ft wide and is now 30-50ft above sea level. This aspect highlights the potential geological changes that can occur in response to climate change, including the emergence of new coastlines and the disappearance of existing ones.

The given aspect states that the landmass rose from the sea surface overnight. This implies that the phenomenon occurred suddenly and relatively quickly, within a single night. It also suggests that the event was not predictable or expected.
A core idea of this aspect is that this event of land rising from the sea surface happened near Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Hokkaido Island, Japan.

The given aspect states that the mass of land which has risen from the sea surface measures roughly 1,000 - 1,640 ft long and 100ft wide. It is a crucial piece of information that indicates the size and dimensions of the newly formed landmass on Shiretoko Peninsula.

The aspect states that the rise of land on the Shiretoko Peninsula is not expected to expand further. This means that the current rise in land above sea level, caused by melting ice and snow, is not likely to increase in size or extend to other areas of the peninsula. This information can help people understand the likely impact of this phenomenon and make informed decisions about how to respond to it.
